newsitem.title: USA: Manufactured Home seen extending offer.
newsitem.headline: Manufactured Home seen extending offer.

text.p: Manufactured Home Communities Inc is expected to extend again its tender offer of $26 a share for Chateau Properties Inc, which is set to expire at midnight Wednesday, analysts said.

In fact, some analysts believe Chateau shareholders expect a higher cash price for the mobile home park operator. These analysts suspect MHC, run by investor Sam Zell, will eventually sweeten the offer.
"I wouldn't be surprised if they (MHC) will extend it again," said Tony Howard, director of research for First of Michigan. "We still believe a higher offer is forthcoming."
David Helfand, MHC's chief executive, said the company is still committed to the transaction and wants to meet with Chateau.
"We can't comment on it, but an extension is clearly one of the options," Helfand said, adding that raising the bid is also "clearly an option".
Chateau has said it remains committed to a "merger of equals" with ROC Communities Inc.
Last month the two companies revised their agreement under which each Chateau share will represent 1.0316 shares of the resulting combined company.

On October 2, MHC extended its offer of $26 a share until midnight October 23. It said it would be willing to consider "an enhanced offer to shareholders" if Chateau agreed to meet with MHC the week the letter was written. They did not meet.

As of October 1, MHC said it controlled about 51 percent of Chateau's outstanding shares -- a number that suprised analysts as low at the time. The MHC offer is subject to shareholders tendering at least two-thirds of the outstanding shares.
The original tender offer was made in September and boosted Chateau's stock to $27 a share.

"I would have to think that a lot of the previous shareholders of Chateau sold when it was over $26, and new shareholders are hoping it gets into a bidding war," said Art Havener, an analyst with A.G. Edwards.
"Many probably bought over $26.... I think we're going to hear more and more from Sam (Zell)," Havener said.
Burl East, an analyst for EVEREN Securities, projected Zell and MHC could afford an offer of $27 a share.
"I ultimately don't know what they're going to do, but they do have room to move," East said.
First of Michigan's Howard said, however, it may take $28 or $30 a share to win. MHC is currently the largest player in the mobile home park industry, but a Chateau/ROC merger would be bigger.
"There is not a real incentive for Chateau not to continue on with the ROC bid," Howard said. "I think everyone is doing like we've done and taken the wait-and-see."
